column23: Satake (2007) found the 1741 Oshima-Oshima tsunami to be related to a subaerial and submarine sector collapse and debris avalanche of ~2.4km3. They describe this landslide as unrelated to tectonic earthquakes (the tsunami size would require a M>8 quake and none are recorded). Debris avalanche deposits back up theory as do reports of activity of Oshima-Oshima that year, suggesting sector collapse of volcanic origin. Damaging tsunami reported as far as the Korean peninsula, though fatalities are only described on the west coast of the Oshima peninsula of Hokkaido (along a 120km stretch) and on the Tsugaru peninsula of Northern Honshu. 1467 fatalities in Hokkaido, not counting the native Ainu (no written records). Hatori (1984) and Tsuji et al (2002) estimate fatalities >2000 including the Ainu. 10 fatalities on Tsugaru peninsula. Affected coastlines of Hokkaido range from 53 - 90 km distance from Oshima Oshima, and Honshu ~85 - 105 km.

Following heavy snowfall a group of 4 ski patrollers were moving a fence bounding the Mammoth Mountain Fumarole, when the snowpack gave way and two of the group fell into the hole and were asphyxiated. A third member of the group climbed in to attempt rescue with a nonrebreathable oxygen mask, but lost consciousness before he could affix it and died. A forth casualty climbed in, but put his mask on just before losing consciousness. He survived. Another patroller lost consciousness during rescue efforts but survived. Nonrebreathable oxygen masks allowed the extraction of victims 3 and 4 (those attempting rescue), and self-contained breathing apparatus worn by the fire department allowed extraction of victims 1 and 2. Many of the rescuers experienced negative effects of the gases and were admitted to hospital.  Victims 1, 2 and 3 had physiological effects consistent with asphyxiation. MMF is associated with very high concentrations of carbon dioxide. Other gases may have played a factor, as might altitude.

column23: Thouret et al (1999) and de Silva et al (2000) describe the impact. Thouret et al (1999): "Repeated tephra falls, pyroclastic flows, and surges buried seven villages, killed ~1500 people (Navarro, 1994), and devastated the landscape within an elliptical area about 70 Ã 40 km west of the volcano. Pyroclastic flows choked the Rio Tambo canyon and reportedly dammed two temporary lakes (Barriga, 1951). The catastrophic breaching of the lakes released large-scale debris flows that swept down the 120-km-long valley to the Pacific Ocean".   De Silva et al (2000): "San Bernardo de Quinistacas (Quinistacas), ~12 km due west of Huaynaputina, where approximately 100 people lived. As described by Barriga (1952), this community and its inhabitants were totally destroyed as âstones began to fall from the sky and many people and animals were killed without giving them a chance to escape.â. ... In the end, all communities within 20 km to the north, west and southwest of the volcano (Ubinas and Omate regions) were completely destroyed. Census data from 1574 and 1578 (in Bouysse-Cassagne, 1988) record a population of more than 1,000 in the Ubinas and Omate regions. Villages such as Quinistacas, Omate, Quinistaquillas, Escobaya, Lloque, Ubinas, Matalaque, and Tasata were razed by falling hot pumice and ash and by earthquakes. ... column23: Thorararinsson (1956) states 'In 1510 the eruption column was carried to the southwest, and fearful showers of rock fell in Landsveit, Rangarvellir, Holt and far into Arnessysla. Huge boulders landed on Vordufell in Skeid, and a man was killed by a falling stone in front of the main entrance at Skalholt".  This is actually located about 40 km distance. However, more recent reference - Thorarinsson 1967 states that the man was killed during evacuation in Landsveit, and that the man in Skalholt was stunned. Although rocks are said to have falled at Vordufell, Gudrun Larsen via Evgenia Ilyinskaya (pers. comm) explains that pre-existing rocks are often noticed and reported during eruptions as freshly fallen. They also explain that the fatality described at 20 km could have occurred within that distance, as he was just described as 'on the run' from the eruption, with no precise location except that he was not far from the main axis of tephra fall direction. Thorarinsson's description of 'East in the country' is an incorrect translation from Icelandic, and in fact refers to Landssveit, south-east of Hekla.
